Field.Definition: Name of person or institute that collected the sample

Field.Brief_description: Amount or size of the collected sample
Field.Definition: The total amount or size (volume (ml), mass (g) or area (m2) ) of sample collected

Field.Brief_description: Date at which the sample was collected
Field.Definition: The time of sampling, either as an instance (single point in time) or interval. In case no exact time is available, the date/time can be right truncated. [ISO8601](https://www.iso.org/iso-8601-date-and-time-format.html) compliant

A unique identifier assigned to a [material sample](http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/terms/materialSampleID) used for extracting nucleic acids, and subsequent sequencing. The identifier can refer either to the original material collected or to any derived sub-samples. The INSDC qualifiers /specimen_voucher, /bio_material, or /culture_collection may or may not share the same value as the source_mat_id field. For instance, the /specimen_voucher qualifier and source_mat_id may both contain 'UAM:Herps:14' , referring to both the specimen voucher and sampled tissue with the same identifier. However, the /culture_collection qualifier may refer to a value from an initial culture (e.g. ATCC:11775) while source_mat_id would refer to an identifier from some derived culture from which the nucleic acids were extracted (e.g. xatc123 or ark:/2154/R2)

Field.Brief_description: project name under which sampling and sequencing was done
Field.Definition: Name of the project within which the sequencing was organized

Biome.name: Terrestrial-Associated
Biome.Example_of_Usage: Roadside Oil Spill Soil Microbiome Study

Field.Brief_description: Temperature at which the sample was stored
Field.Definition: Temperature at which sample was stored, e.g. -80 ˚C
Temperature of the sample at the time of sampling

The total concentration of all dissolved salts in a liquid or solid sample. While salinity can be measured by a complete chemical analysis, this method is difficult and time consuming. More often, it is instead derived from the conductivity measurement. This is known as practical salinity. These derivations compare the specific conductance of the sample to a salinity standard such as seawater
Stage of the disease at the time of sample collection, e.g. inoculation, penetration, infection, growth and reproduction, dissemination of pathogen
Any other measurement performed or parameter collected, that is not listed here

Biome.name: Marine-Associated
Biome.Example_of_Usage: light–dark cycle 12 h:12 h; squid reared in flow-through seawater

Field.Definition: Oxygenation status of sample

Type of perturbation, e.g. chemical administration, physical disturbance, etc., coupled with perturbation regimen including how many times the perturbation was repeated, how long each perturbation lasted, and the start and end time of the entire perturbation period; can include multiple perturbation types

Biome.name: Animal-Associated
Biome.Example_of_Usage: praziquantel 5 mg kg⁻¹ PO, 24 h pre-sampling

Biome.name: Human-Associated
Biome.Example_of_Usage: Amoxicillin [CHEBI:2676](https://www.ebi.ac.uk/chebi/searchId.do?chebiId=CHEBI:2676); 500 mg orally, 3× day for 7 days

Field.Definition: A local identifier or name that for the material sample used for extracting nucleic acids, and subsequent sequencing. It can refer either to the original material collected or to any derived sub-samples. It can have any format, but we suggest that you make it concise, unique and consistent within your lab, and as informative as possible. INSDC requires every sample name from a single Submitter to be unique. Use of a globally unique identifier for the field source_mat_id is recommended in addition to sample_name

Field.Brief_description: Microbiological culture medium (applicable only if microorganism can be cultivated)
Field.Definition: Composition of processed material providing the needed nourishment for microorganisms or cells to grow in vitro. This field accepts terms listed under culture medium [OBI:0000079](https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ols4/ontologies/mco/classes/http%253A%252F%252Fpurl.obolibrary.org%252Fobo%252FOBI_0000079?lang=en). If the proper descriptor is not listed please use text to describe the culture medium

Field.Brief_description: Solution in which the sample was stored
Field.Definition: Solution within which sample was stored, if any

NCBI taxon id of the sample. Maybe be a single taxon or mixed taxa sample. Use ‘synthetic metagenome for mock community/positive controls, or ’blank sample’ for negative controls. Expected_value: [NCBI taxonomy ID](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/taxonomy)
The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude and longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees, limited to 8 decimal points, and in WGS84 system

Geographic location (country and/or sea,region). The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea name followed by specific region name. Country or sea names should be chosen from the [INSDC country list](https://www.insdc.org/submitting-standards/country-qualifier-vocabulary/), or the [GAZ ontology](http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/GAZ)

Report the major environmental system the sample or specimen came from. Systems(s) identifiers should provide a coarse, general environmental context of where the sampling was done. Recommended use of EnvO s biome class: [ENVO_00000428](https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ols4/ontologies/envo/classes/http%253A%252F%252Fpurl.obolibrary.org%252Fobo%252FENVO_00000428?lang=en). If more than one term applies to the field, <|> should be used to separate them.

Report the entity or entities which are in the sample or specimen’s local vicinity and which you believe have significant causal influences on your sample or specimen. Entry should be of a smaller environmental context than env_broad_scale. Terms, such as anatomical sites, from other [OBO Library](https://obofoundry.org/) ontologies which interoperate with EnvO (e.g. [UBERON](https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ols4/ontologies/uberon)) are accepted in this field. If more than one term applies to the field, <|> should be used to separate them.

Report the environmental material(s) immediately surrounding the sample or specimen at the time of sampling. Recommended use of EnvO’s subclasses of environmental material [ENVO:00010483](http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_00010483). Terms from other [OBO ontologies](https://obofoundry.org/) are permissible as long as they reference mass/volume nouns (e.g. air, water, blood) and not discrete, countable entities (e.g. a tree, a leaf, a table top). If more than one term applies to the field, <|> should be used to separate them.
The vertical distance below local surface. For sediment or soil samples depth is measured from sediment or soil surface, respectively. Depth can be reported as an interval for subsurface samples

Elevation of the sampling site is its height above a fixed reference point, most commonly the mean sea level. Elevation is mainly used when referring to points on the earth's surface, while altitude is used for points above the surface, such as an aircraft in flight or a spacecraft in orbit. Origin elevation in m

Heights of objects such as airplanes, space shuttles, rockets, atmospheric balloons and heights of places such as atmospheric layers and clouds. It is used to measure the height of an object which is above the earth's surface. In this context, the altitude measurement is the vertical distance between the earth's surface above sea level and the sampled position in the air

Field.Brief_description: List of chemical administered to sampled host or site
Field.Definition: List of chemical compounds administered to host or on site where sampling occurred. Can include multiple compounds separated by <|>. For compounds consult [chemical entities of biological interest ontology (chebi) (v 163)](http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/chebi)

Biome.name: WasteWater-Associated
Biome.Example_of_Usage: Ferric chloride [SNOMED:420810003](http 25 mg Fe L⁻¹; continuous; start 2023-05-01T00:00Z; end 2023-05-31T23:59Z://snomed.info/id/420810003);

Field.Brief_description: Disease status of the sampled host
Field.Definition: List of diseases with which the host has been diagnosed; can include multiple diagnoses. The value of the field depends on host, non-human host diseases are free text.

Field.Brief_description: Common name of the sampled host
Field.Definition: Common name of the host
NCBI taxon id of the host [NCBI taxonomy ID](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/taxonomy)

Field.Brief_description: Life stage of the sampled host
Field.Definition: Description of life stage of host
Age of host at the time of sampling; relevant scale depends on species and study, e.g. Could be seconds for amoebae or centuries for trees
The length of host
The color of host
Morphological shape of host

Field.Brief_description: Total mass of the sampled host
Field.Definition: Total mass of the host at collection, the unit depends on host
The height of subject
Core body temperature of the host when sample was collected
Observed genotype

Biome.name: Plant-Associated
Biome.Example_of_Usage: cv. Williams 82 genome Wm82.a2.v1, WGS: ACUP01000000

Field.Definition: Genetic modifications of the genome of an organism, which may occur naturally by spontaneous mutation, or be introduced by some experimental means, e.g. specification of a transgene or the gene knocked-out or details of transient transfection
A unique identifier by which each subject can be referred to, de-identified

Field.Brief_description: Physical sex of the sampled host
Field.Definition: Physical sex of the host
Original body habitat where the sample was obtained from

Field.Brief_description: Sampled body site of the host
Field.Definition: Name of body site where the sample was obtained from, such as a specific organ or tissue (tongue, lung etc…). Recomended use of [FMA](https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ols4/ontologies/fma) or [UBERON](https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ols4/ontologies/uberon) ontologies
Type of diet depending on the host, for animals omnivore, herbivore etc., for humans high-fat, meditteranean etc.<;> can include multiple diet types

Biome.name: Marine-Associated
Biome.Example_of_Usage: Microcarnivore [ECOCORE:00000170](http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ECOCORE_00000170), post-larval diet of mysid shrimp

Field.Definition: Literature reference giving growth conditions of the host
Phenotype of human or other host. Use terms from the phenotypic quality ontology (pato) or the Human Phenotype Ontology (HP)
Whether or not subject is gravid, and if yes date due or date post-conception, specifying which is used

Field.Brief_description: Body product that was examined and sampled from host
Field.Definition: Substance produced by the body, e.g. Stool, mucus, where the sample was obtained from. Use terms from the foundational model of anatomy ontology [FMA](https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ols4/ontologies/fma) or Uber-anatomy ontology [UBERON](https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ols4/ontologies/uberon).

The taxonomic name of the organism(s) found living in mutualistic, commensalistic, or parasitic symbiosis with the specific host. The sampled symbiont can have its own symbionts. For example, parasites may have hyperparasites (=parasites of the parasite)

Field.Brief_description: type of symbiosis with sampled host
Field.Definition: Type of biological interaction established between the symbiotic host organism being sampled and its respective host

Field.Brief_description: Specificity of symbiont of the sampled host
Field.Definition: Level of specificity of symbiont-host interaction: e.g. generalist (symbiont able to establish associations with distantly related hosts) or species-specific

Field.Brief_description: Cellular location of symbiont within the sampled host
Field.Definition: The localization of the symbiotic host organism within the host from which it was sampled: e.g. intracellular if the symbiotic host organism is localized within the cells or extracellular if the symbiotic host organism is localized outside of cells
A brief description of any processing applied to the sample during or after retrieving the sample from environment, or a link to the relevant protocol(s) performed

Biome.name: BuiltEnvironment-Associated
Biome.Example_of_Usage: dust collected via sterile nylon-filter vacuum; sieved < 300 µm; stored −80 °C

Field.Definition: Total cell count of any organism (or group of organisms) per gram, volume or area of sample; include organism name, count and enumeration method (e.g. qPCR)

Biome.name: Terrestrial-Associated
Biome.Example_of_Usage: total prokaryotes; 4.2e8 cells g⁻¹; Real Time PCR [NCIT:C51962](http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/NCIT_C51962)

Biome.name: Marine-Associated
Biome.Example_of_Usage: *Vibrio fischeri* ES114 [NCBI:txid312309](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Taxonomy/BNCIT:C51962rohttp://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/NCIT_C51962wser/wwwtax.cgi?mode=Info&id=312309&lvl=3&p=has_linkout&p=blast_url&p=genome_blast&lin=f&keep=1&srchmode=1&unlock); 1 × 10⁷ cells mL⁻¹; Real Time PCR [NCIT:C51962](http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/NCIT_C51962)

Biome.name: BuiltEnvironment-Associated
Biome.Example_of_Usage: total bacteria; 2.1 × 10⁶ cells cm⁻²; Real Time PCR [NCIT:C51962](http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/NCIT_C51962)

Field.Definition: Duration for which the sample was stored. Indicate the duration for which the sample was stored written in ISO 8601 format
Water content measurement
Concentration of organic matter
Concentration of organic nitrogen
Collection design of pooled samples and/or sieve size and amount of sample sieved
Indicate whether multiple DNA extractions were mixed. If the answer yes, the number of extracts that were pooled should be given
Explain how and for how long the soil sample was stored before DNA extraction (fresh/frozen/other)
Total carbon content
Total nitrogen content of the sample
Total organic carbon content

Treatment involving use of mutagens; should include the name of mutagen, amount administered, treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple mutagen regimens

Information about treatment involving the use of fertilizers; should include the name of fertilizer, amount administered, treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple fertilizer regimens

Biome.name: Plant-Associated
Biome.Example_of_Usage: Urea Ammonium Nitrate Solution (UAN); 30 kg N ha⁻¹; applied once (1×); 1 h application; start 2013-02-10; end 2013-02-10

Field.Definition: Information about treatment involving use of fungicides; should include the name of fungicide, amount administered, treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple fungicide regimens

Information about treatment involving use of herbicides; should include the name of herbicide, amount administered, treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple regimens

Biome.name: Plant-Associated
Biome.Example_of_Usage: glyphosate [CHEBI:27744]; 1.2 kg a.i. ha⁻¹; applied once (1×); 2 h boom-spray; start 2013-02-10; end 2013-02-10

Field.Definition: Information about treatment involving an exposure to varying degree of humidity; should include amount of humidity administered, treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple regimens
Information about treatment(s) involving exposure to light, including both light intensity and quality

Information about treatment involving the use of mineral supplements; should include the name of mineral nutrient, amount administered, treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple mineral nutrient regimens

Information about treatment involving exposure of plant to non-mineral nutrients such as oxygen, hydrogen or carbon; should include the name of non-mineral nutrient, amount administered, treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple regimens

Information about treatment involving use of insecticides; should include the name of pesticide, amount administered, treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple pesticide regimens

Information about treatment involving exposure of plant or a plant part to a particular radiation regimen; should include the radiation type, amount or intensity administered, treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple radiation regimens

Information about treatment involving an exposure to a given amount of rainfall; should include treatment regimen details such as how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple regimens

Biome.name: Plant-Associated
Biome.Example_of_Usage: Simulated storm rainfall; 50 mm per event (25 mm h⁻¹ intensity); applied twice (2×) at 48 h intervals; 2 h per event; start 2013-01-10; end 2013-01-14 | Low-intensity drizzle; 10 mm per event (5 mm h⁻¹); applied daily (14×); 30 min per event; start 2024-02-01; end 2024-02-15

Field.Definition: Information about treatment involving use of salts as supplement to liquid and soil growth media; should include the name of salt, amount administered, treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple salt regimens
Addition of fertilizers, pesticides, etc. – amount and time of applications

The part of the organic matter in the soil that constitutes living microorganisms smaller than 5–10 µm. If you keep this, you would need to have correction factors used for conversion to the final units
Heavy metals present in the sequenced sample and their concentrations. For multiple heavy metals and concentrations, add multiple copies of this field

Biome.name: Terrestrial-Associated
Biome.Example_of_Usage: Pb [CHEBI:27889](http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/CHEBI_27889) 50 mg kg⁻¹| Zn [CHEBI:36560](http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/CHEBI_36560) 150 mg kg⁻¹

Field.Definition: Total amount or concentration of phosphate
Ph measurement of the sample, or liquid portion of sample, or aqueous phase of the fluid
Information about treatment(s) involving use of biotic factors, such as bacteria, viruses or fungi
Amount of water vapour in the air, at the time of sampling
The amount of solar energy that arrives at a specific area of a surface during a specific time interval
Vegetation classification from one or more standard classification systems, or agricultural crop
Previous land use and dates
Historical and/or physical evidence of flooding
Unusual physical events that may have affected microbial populations
Description of the soil type or classification. This field accepts terms under [soil [\ENVO_00001998\]](http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_00001998). Multiple terms can be separated by |s

The relative proportion of different grain sizes of mineral particles in a soil, as described using a standard system; express as % sand (50 µm–2 mm), silt (2 µm–50 µm), and clay (< 2 µm) with textural name optional
The type and number of animals or insects present in the sampling space
The season when sampling occurred; terms listed under ‘season’ ontology
Present state of land use at the sample site
Specific layer in the land area which measures parallel to the soil surface and possesses physical characteristics which differ from the layers above and beneath

Soil classification from the FAO World soil distribution from International Soil Reference and Information Centre (ISRIC). The list of available soil classifications can be found at https://www.isric.org/explore/world-soil-distribution
Historical and/or physical evidence of fire
Description of environmental systems or features adjacent to the sampling site
Material covering the sampled soil. This field accepts terms under environmental material [ENVO:00010483](http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_00010483)
Ph measurement of the soil
Location of sampled soil relative to other parts of the farm e.g. under crop plant, near irrigation ditch, from the dirt road

Biome.name: Terrestrial-Associated
Biome.Example_of_Usage: 1 m from asphalt edge, 20 m from agricultural field

Field.Definition: Temperature of soil at the time of sampling
To what is the entity pathogenic

Description of relationship(s) between the subject organism and other organism(s) it is associated with. E.g., parasite on species X; mutualist with species Y. The target organism is the subject of the relationship, and the other organism(s) is the object

Information about treatment involving use of growth hormones; should include the name of growth hormone, amount administered, treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple growth hormone regimens

Information about treatment involving an exposure to watering frequencies, treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple regimens

Name or reference for the hydroponic or in vitro culture rooting medium; can be the name of a commonly used medium or reference to a specific medium, e.g. Murashige and Skoog medium. If the medium has not been formally published, use the rooting medium descriptors

Biome.name: Plant-Associated
Biome.Example_of_Usage: nitrogen-free plant nutrient solution (Beck et al., 2013; https://hdl.handle.net/20.500.11766/67561)

Field.Definition: Information about treatment involving exposure of plants to varying levels of ph of the growth media, treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple regimen

Field.Brief_description: Medium used to grow plant samples
Field.Definition: Specification of the media for growing the plants or tissue cultured samples, e.g. soil, aeroponic, hydroponic, in vitro solid culture medium, in vitro liquid culture medium. Recommended value is a specific value from EO:plant growth medium (follow this link for termshttp://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/EO_0007147) or other controlled vocabulary

Type of fertilizer or amendment added to the soil or water for the purpose of improving substrate health and quality for plant growth. This field accepts terms listed under agronomic fertilizer [AGRO:00002062](http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/AGRO_00002062). Multiple terms may apply and can be separated by |s, listing in reverse chronological order

Measurement of photosythetic activity (i.e. leaf gas exchange / chlorophyll fluorescence emissions / reflectance / transpiration) Please also include the term method term detailing the method of activity measurement
Whether or not crop is rotated, and if yes, rotation schedule
Type of facility where the sampled plant was grown; controlled vocabulary: growth chamber, open top chamber, glasshouse, experimental garden, field.
Amount of crop produced per unit or area of land
Substance produced by the plant, where the sample was obtained from
Sex of the reproductive parts on the whole plant

Name of plant structure the sample was obtained from, such as a specific organ or tissue (epidermis, etc…). Recommended use of plant anatomical entity [PO:0025131](http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/PO_0025131) subclasses
Relevant rooting conditions such as field plot size, sowing density, container dimensions, number of plants per container

Biome.name: Plant-Associated
Biome.Example_of_Usage: Open-field research plot 5 m × 20 m (100 m²); sowing density ≈ 350 000 seeds ha⁻¹ (~35 seeds m⁻²) with 0.5 m inter-row spacing; no containers; single plant per sowing position.

Field.Definition: pH measurement of the culture rooting medium; e.g. 5.5
Specification of the solidifying agent in the culture rooting medium; e.g. agar
Description of plant tissue culture growth media used

Type of life cycle of the symbiotic host species (the thing being sampled). Simple life cycles occur within a single host, complex ones within multiple different hosts over the course of their normal life cycle
Type of host dependence for the symbiotic host organism to its host

Information about the genetic distinctness of the host organism below the subspecies level e.g., serovar, serotype, biotype, ecotype, variety, cultivar, or any relevant genetic typing schemes like Group I plasmid. Subspecies should not be recorded in this term, but in the NCBI taxonomy. Supply both the lineage name and the lineage rank separated by a colon, e.g., biovar:abc123
Trophic levels are the feeding position in a food chain. Microbes can be a range of producers (e.g. chemolithotroph)
Alkalinity, the ability of a solution to neutralize acids to the equivalence point of carbonate or bicarbonate
Concentration of nitrate in the sample
Sodium concentration in the sample
Concentration of phosphate
Amount of dissolved oxygen needed by aerobic biological organisms in a body of water to break down organic material present in a given water sample at certain temperature over a specific time period
A measure of the capacity of water to consume oxygen during the decomposition of organic matter and the oxidation of inorganic chemicals such as ammonia and nitrite
Amount or concentration of substances such as hydrogen sulfide, carbon dioxide, methane, etc.; can include multiple substances
Concentration of substances such as ammonia, road-salt, sea-salt, cyanide, hydrogen sulfide, thiocyanates, thiosulfates, etc
Concentration of substances such as urea, fruit sugars, soluble proteins, drugs, pharmaceuticals, etc

Biome.name: WasteWater-Associated
Biome.Example_of_Usage: Urea [CHEBI:16199](http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/CHEBI_16199); 5 mg L⁻¹ <|> glucose [CHEBI:17234](http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/CHEBI_17234); 2 mg L⁻¹

Field.Definition: Physical combination of several instances of like material, e.g. RNA extracted from samples or dishes of cell cultures into one big aliquot of cells. Please provide a short description of the samples that were pooled
Type of wastewater treatment plant as municipial or industrial
The process of pre-treatment removes materials that can be easily collected from the raw wastewater
The process to produce both a generally homogeneous liquid capable of being treated biologically and a sludge that can be separately treated or processed

Biome.name: WasteWater-Associated
Biome.Example_of_Usage: primary clarifier sedimentation producing primary sludge

Field.Definition: Anaerobic digesters can be designed and engineered to operate using a number of different process configurations, as batch or continuous, mesophilic, high solid or low solid, and single stage or multistage
The process for substantially degrading the biological content of the sewage
The process providing a final treatment stage to raise the effluent quality before it is discharged to the receiving environment
The origin of wastewater such as human waste, rainfall, storm drains, etc

Information about treatment involving an exposure to water with varying degree of temperature, treatment regimen including how many times the treatment was repeated, how long each treatment lasted, and the start and end time of the entire treatment; can include multiple regimens
Percentage of volatile solids removed from the anaerobic digestor
Percentage of industrial effluents received by wastewater treatment plant
Concentration of particles such as sand, grit, metal particles, ceramics, etc.; can include multiple particles

Biome.name: WasteWater-Associated
Biome.Example_of_Usage: Sand [SNOMED:128489003](http://snomed.info/id/128489003); 50 mg L⁻¹ | grit [SNOMED:264359001](http://snomed.info/id/264359001); 20 mg L⁻¹

Field.Definition: Concentration of particles such as faeces, hairs, food, vomit, paper fibers, plant material, humus, etc
The time activated sludge remains in reactor
Total phosphorus concentration in the sample, calculated by: total phosphorus = total dissolved phosphorus + particulate phosphorus
Concentration of dissolved oxygen
Amount of biomass; should include the name for the part of biomass measured, e.g. Microbial, total. Can include multiple measurements
Concentration of chlorophyll

Particles are classified, based on their size, into six general categories:clay, silt, sand, gravel, cobbles, and boulders; should include amount of particle preceded by the name of the particle type; can include multiple values
Concentration of sulfate in the sample
Concentration of sulfide in the sample
Concentration of nitrite in the sample
Concentration of ammonium in the sample
Concentration of chloride in the sample
Concentration of potassium in the sample
Concentration of magnesium in the sample
Concentration of calcium in the sample
Density of the sample, which is its mass per unit volume (aka volumetric mass density)
Concentration of nitrogen (total)
Concentration of petroleum hydrocarbon

Field.Brief_description: Type of sediment of sample (if applicable)
Field.Definition: Information about the sediment type based on major constituents
Carbon dioxide (gas) amount or concentration at the time of sampling
Partial vapor and air pressure, density of the vapor and air, or by the actual mass of the vapor and air
Temperature of the air at the time of sampling
Temperature of the surface at the time of sampling
Water held on a surface
The unit of illuminance and luminous emittance, measuring luminous flux per unit area
The age of the built structure since construction
The area of the floor space within the room
The recorded value at sampling time (power density)
The length, width and height of sampling room
Volume of sampling room
The recorded temperature value at sampling time outside
Average number of occupants at time of sampling per square footage
The street name and building number where the sampling occurred

Biome.name: BuiltEnvironment-Associated
Biome.Example_of_Usage: 123 Main St., Apt 5B, New York, NY 10001

Field.Definition: The window's length and width
The number of floors in the building, including basements and mechanical penthouse
The number of times the sample location is cleaned. Frequency of cleaning might be on a Daily basis, Weekly, Monthly, Quarterly or Annually
The number of plant(s) in the sampling space
The number of pets residing in the sampled space
The number of individuals currently occupying in the sampling location
The total count of rooms in the built structure including all room types

Field.Brief_description: room moisture damage or mold history
Field.Definition: The history of moisture damage or mold in the past 12 months. Number of events of moisture damage or mold observed
Count of room occupancy at time of sampling
Number of windows in the room
Sampling room number. This ID should be consistent with the designations on the building floor plans
Ventilation system used in the sampled premises
Surface materials at the point of sampling
The primary function for which a building or discrete part of a building is intended to be used
Type of indoor surface
A device which removes solid particulates or airborne molecular contaminants
Methods of conditioning or heating a room or building
A location (geography) where a building is set

Application of light to achieve some practical or aesthetic effect. Lighting includes the use of both artificial light sources such as lamps and light fixtures, as well as natural illumination by capturing daylight. Can also include absence of light
Number of occupants present at time of sample within the given space
The characterization of the location of the built structure as high or low human density
The physical condition of the floor at the time of sampling; photos or video preferred; use drawings to indicate location of damaged areas
The floor covering type; the finished surface that is walked on
Signs of the presence of mold or mildew in a room
The gender type of the restroom
The last time the floor was cleaned (swept, mopped, vacuumed)
The condition of the room at the time of sampling
The main purpose or activity of the sampling room. A room is any distinguishable space within a structure
The floor of the building, where the sampling room is located
Signs of the presence of mold or mildew on a wall
Signs of the presence of mold or mildew on the window
The type of windows
Specification of smoking status

Field.Brief_description: presence of pets or farm animals around sampled host
Field.Definition: Specification of presence of pets or farm animals in the environment of subject, if yes the animals should be specified; can include multiple animals present
Current sexual partner and frequency of sex
Body mass index, calculated as weight/(height)squared
